title.narrative: Responding to Health needs of Hawija IDPs

description.narrative: The main goal of this project is to respond to the health needs of the displaced IDPs of Hawija for 3 months. WVI will provide primary health care (PHC) including consultations, health education, MHPSS and reproductive health services (PNC,ANC, etc.) to IDPs in Kirkuk governorate. Under the proposed project, one mobile clinic and one static will serve Kirkuk governorate. The static mobile clinic will serve Laylan C camp which was was established to receive IDPs fleeing from Hawija and one mobile clinic that will be in close proximity to IDP screening centers or checkpoints depending on the needs and gaps. providing coverage of essential health services to 7500 IDPs fleeing from Hawija after the liberation who currently have lack alternative access to health and psycho social services. WV will utilize core materials on health and mental health developed and contextualized during operational projects to disseminate messages through participatory community-based awareness sessions. An Early Warning and Alert Response Network (EWARN), which includes disease and nutritional surveillance, will also be operationalized in order to monitor epidemiological trends for key illnesses and nutritional status of children this will be closely coordinated with the respective governorate and the World Health Organization (WHO). This emergency response project is being proposed as a result of extensive coordination and collaborative efforts between World Vision and the Department of Health (DOH) in Kirkuk governorate as well as the national and sub-national health clusters. The proposed interventions have been prioritized by the UN health cluster and are directly aligned with the health cluster’s strategic objective of “saving lives through the provision of critical life-saving health interventions reaching the most vulnerable people across Iraq,” as outlined in the Humanitarian Response Plan (HRP) 2017.
